Posts.Content: You are delaying something important , potentially life altering , for what ? RP is often not that big a deal. The only reason I would suggest delaying any further is for you to get yourself in the best shape possible. No that doesn't mean go for a walk once a week and skip a donut. That means get your core muscles fit, do your levels til you are a kegal machine. Then you will be ready for Rp and will have given yourself the best chance at a good recovery. Too many don't do anything g and then regret it. This is important treat it so. I did the above and my RP is now a distant foggy memory with no real side affects.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by njs Hi gsteve, What are those "known reasons" in your mind? The only clear advantage vs open is less blood loss and open has some advantages over robotic so it should come down to picking the surgeon who can offer you the best record of results and then leting him use whatever tools he uses. (I don't mean to sound like a broken record but I get the impression you missed what I said in the other thread and want to make sure you understand) I do agree with the others on the recovery process - with either open or robotic approach you'll probably feel great after 2 weeks, but you need to watch the lifting and other exertion or you risk a hernia. As far as the incision for open surgery, my doctor did everything through a only a single 3 inch incision that starts about 3 inches below my belly button and goes down from there. Because the muscle fibers run vertically they are not cut but just separated, which is by contrast to the circular trocars used for robotic (especially the one that needs to be enlarged to remove the intact specimen for pathology) that can cause more muscle trauma. So far just about every dr I've spoken with and most things I've found online say the da vinci gives you a better percentage at ed and incontinence issues. This only what i have found and I'm sure there is more stats I'm not seeing. My first dr i saw was a surgeon and maybe he was over stating to be sure i wasn't disappointed in the end but his percentages scared the crap outta me.

Posts.Content: Hi All ! Im glad to see this amazing resource is so active ! Its still the best place to help those in our club. I posted a bit of my latest info on another members thread but didnt want to hijack it any more than i did. I dont have all the lab results handy but will get them but here is what i remember. psa was 8.5 at time of surgery age 53 was a fair bit of cancer volume , over 50% i think biopsy said 3+3 lab post surgery said it was 3+4 lab said there was a positive margin at the bladder neck , surgeon felt it was minor and possibly even scar tissue. my recovery was "gold star" according to my surgeon, 90% dry in 6 weeks , id say 99% in 6 months. ED not a concern by about 6 month , overall i was and am very happy with how things turned out. So i chose to get psa tests every 3 months for the last 4 years they were always .01 , last one was .02. had it rechecked 2 weeks later .02 still. I met with my GP today , i have to say i think i know more than he does about most prostate cancer issues but what ever. He says the normal range for someone in my shoes is 00 -3.95. Ok thats all well and fine but here is my question for the experts here.... If i no longer have a prostate and a increase of psa means the cancer has reappeared why is any increase considered normal? Let alone a increase of 40x? Dont get me wrong , if thats normal im happy but if its really a positive sign of the cancer starting up im not going to wait around for it to really take off , ill seek radiation asap. Of course radiation is not without its downsides so i dont want to jump into that without good cause either. Thanks in advance for the help and thanks for maintaining this site the way you do. The key members here spend so much time helping others and I hope they know just how much they are appreciated. Steve j
Posts.Title: slight increase in psa 4 years post robotic

Posts.Content: Thanks Guys and Pratoman thats very interesting info. I guess my plan is now is keep monitoring and more research. Thanks Again !

Posts.Content: You Have some hard questions to ask your surgeon. He may be a black belt in removing a prostate , but how is his rate of success on nerve sparring ? That is the key. Really almost any prostate surgeon can remove your prostate and you will no longer have a cancer , the difference is how will you be once done. Where i live we have two great open surgeons , or so they say they are , they judge success by "do you still have cancer No = success. But today there is more to it. Good continence and functioning sexual organs are now very possible. There in lies the difference , robotic surgery has a much higher rate of success in those areas. Granted some open surgeons are very successful all around ,,,, is yours?

Posts.Content: I can't add much that isn't in the stickies. Try to get used to sleeping on just your back. I'm a roller a rounder and that's hard to do with a cath. Get a long shoe lace or something to put around your neck to hang the bag from while moving around the house. Remember it has to be lower than you, ie on the floor most of the time. I didn't have too much trouble with the leg strap but did adjust it a few times. Getting that just right is important as you want no tugging going on !!!!

Posts.Content: Hi. I went 5years post robotic surgery before my psa started going up. I knew there was a chance it would. 38 sessions of SRT was what i did. I was a bit surprised that it wasnt too difficult. I did seem a bit more tired mid day but no big deal. Dropping a duce became difficult at the half way mark so I made sure to continue the milk of magnesia as they suggested. My lower unit burned pretty good , like my diet was tequila and Mexican. Good luck and feel free to ask any questions. Love this place !

Posts.Content: A year and a few weeks actually. I thought Id give a quick write up as to how things have gone. - robotic surgery was recommended over seeds due to the size of the growths - it was done sept 20 and the lab report said there was 1.5mm protruding into the bladder - surgeon said well there is a 50/50 it could return but don't fret - I was 90% continent at the 4-5 week mark the only time I get a mini squirt is when I force a fart - ED was an issue for about 6 mons and then I started to get a bit of action - I take 5mg a cpl times a week and 50-100 of Viagra when I'm hoping for a bit of fun - with the Viagra things probably work better than before the surgery. With no V it's 50/50 if I'll get any reaction down under. - the V gives me a good headache so my pre fun routine is 100. Mg of V and tylonal -my psa tests have all been undetectable so far. - I get random pangs in the abdomen but nothing to worry about -I'm going to the mayo in nov for a complete check over Over all the surgery was no real big deal. At the time it sure was. It's seems like a bad dream now really. I credit 80% of the education I got and badly needed to this forum. You guys are great !!!!! Thank you!!!! Sj

Posts.Title: Old stickies???

Posts.Content: I wish I was the expert required to answer those. All I can do is try to repeat what I asked and was told. I had 6mm of positive margin extending into the bladder neck. I have Gleason 7 not sure which variety. I was told the odds are 80 % it will return somewhere between 2-6 years. I was told by both a 30 year mayo prostate surgeon and the leading radiologist at the mayo that waiting for a increase in psa before going to for radiation is a BAD idea. A rough graph was. 0 psa cure highly probable .01 psa 70%. .02 50-60%. .05 psa 30% chance of curing. I then asked , what reason would I chose not to radiate, would I go backwards in my recovery? He said there is NO reason not to and at worst I will need to pee more often than normal for a month. When I get home I'm scheduling my radiation asap.

Posts.Content: I will get the pathology report and results of my first psa test in two days. I have myself pretty convinced that due to my sore of six amd age 53 that he will say ally's good. But I'm also ready for " you need radiation to mop up". At the 5 week mark I'd say my continence is at around 85%. I've gone a week with out pads but occasionally feel the odd squirt. I can't really feel any of the incisions any more. ED is getting better, I get maybe 70% hard. I take 5 mg of cialis every other day. I'd have to say I'm fairly pleased , I'd given myself a date of jan 1 to be doing this well. Thanks again to everyone on here !

Posts.Title: 2 years since divinci

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobertG Like getting a colonoscopy, the prep work is worse than the procedure. I've been through this prep work 4 times now between colonoscopy, biopsy, and brachytherapy. You go on a clear fluid diet and take Pico-Salax which clears your system out through jet-powered pooping. They may or may not also ask you to do a Fleet enema. I recommend taking the day off work before the procedure, it's a lot of time in the bathroom. Follow the instructions carefully so that you don't have to do it again - they need you clean as a whistle so they can get a good look. this is pretty bang on , the biopsy itself is no biggie. Painless too.

Posts.Content: I don't recall all the details but the brunt of it was that I had positive margins. Very small ones. Near the bladder neck. My surgeon from calgary told me there is many reasons for a positive margin and not all of them are cancer. A year after having the operation I went to the mayo for a executive physical and they told me as I said above. I called my surgeon and told him what the mayo said and he disagreed. I saw my local radiologist and told him what the mayo said. He also disagreed that I should have radiation without any rise in psa. He did say that if it were up to him I would have had radiation about six weeks after my surgery to make sure that positive margin was cleared off. He said that now that I had gone at that time 18 months my gamble had paid off and I didn't need it. The dr at the mayo said I should get it ASAP that the sooner they go after it the better.

Posts.Title: Salvage Radiation Experiences?

Posts.Content: So.... It's been 14 months since my surgery and I'm very happy with the results. I'm at the mayo this week getting a few things checked on and met with a surgeon today to go over my recovery. He is very pleased with where I am. I'd say I'm around 90% of where I was pre Surgery. BUT.... I did have positive margins in the bladder neck. Of all the areas this is the one he says concerns him. My psa is 00.00 so we know nothing is showing up as of yet. He is hinting that I should have the bladder neck area radiated because it's better to do it before any psa increase. My fear is that the radiation will damage the great recovery I've enjoyed or maybe damage me and I don't get back to where was. Can anybody shed light on the side effects specifically ED and incontinance after radiation. Thanks sj
Posts.Title: Radiation after robotic removal

Posts.Content: So I just spoke to the radiologist at the mayo. He says with a Gleason of 7 and positive margins the cancer is coming back for sure. When who knows. I asked what negative affects will I see. He says you will pee more often for a month. Man why can't I have gotten this info before ???? I was under the impression there was a 50/50 chance of it coming back and if it does, radiate then, no big deal. Not so, once the psa is detected it's on the move and success is no where near as good as when the psa is at zero.

Posts.Title: 19 Days post DaVinci Surgery - My Update

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobertG Like getting a colonoscopy, the prep work is worse than the procedure. I've been through this prep work 4 times now between colonoscopy, biopsy, and brachytherapy. You go on a clear fluid diet and take Pico-Salax which clears your system out through jet-powered pooping. They may or may not also ask you to do a Fleet enema. I recommend taking the day off work before the procedure, it's a lot of time in the bathroom. Follow the instructions carefully so that you don't have to do it again - they need you clean as a whistle so they can get a good look. this is pretty bang on , the biopsy itself is no biggie. Painless too.

Posts.Title: recooping after surgery

Posts.Content: I don't recall all the details but the brunt of it was that I had positive margins. Very small ones. Near the bladder neck. My surgeon from calgary told me there is many reasons for a positive margin and not all of them are cancer. A year after having the operation I went to the mayo for a executive physical and they told me as I said above. I called my surgeon and told him what the mayo said and he disagreed. I saw my local radiologist and told him what the mayo said. He also disagreed that I should have radiation without any rise in psa. He did say that if it were up to him I would have had radiation about six weeks after my surgery to make sure that positive margin was cleared off. He said that now that I had gone at that time 18 months my gamble had paid off and I didn't need it. The dr at the mayo said I should get it ASAP that the sooner they go after it the better.
Posts.Title: 2 years since divinci

Posts.Content: Psa still at zero. All my plumbing is working fine and has been for about a year. I still use Ed drugs because , well they work great ! There has been times where the " fun" was spontaneous and I didn't pop a vitamin C or V and everything worked fine. The talk I had with the mayo is still on my mind. They were quite adamant that after divinci you get radiation. No one else seems to agree. I will continue to get psa tests and will radiate at the first increase

Posts.Content: Hi Ronny. I understand the Vancouver center is very good. I went to Calgary because it is closer for me and I heard good things about the surgeon there. I did a fair bit of research and came to a few conclusions. Of course number one is the skill of the surgeon. There is many who do open in the states that I have heard great things about. There is many I have heard of in canada that are horrible. I decided to look for the best robotic surgeon. That's what I suggest you do. If you don't get. Good feeling from any of them and want the name of my dr in Calgary let me know. One thing I found is that the Canadian hospitals are much more .... I don't know ... Considerate ? When I asked about getting out the next day as I read about happening in most American hospitals. I was told. Are you kidding you will be here at least three or four days. I found those extra days very benificial. You mention being on your own. How alone? Is there ppl who can stop in , help out ? If not you will need to prepare. Heck you will need to prepare anyway. Read thru here and we will all help you out. If you want to call me just ask.
